The leases are located within a few kilometres of the gold mining centres of Peak Hill, 
 Horseshoe Lights, Horseshoe, Cassidy, Labouchere and Fortnum.  
 E52/2115 is a granted exploration licence within the Peak Hill Mineral Field in Western

14.text: underlain by Recent and Tertiary alluvium of the Gascoyne River. This alluvium includes

15.text: Recent channels as well as Tertiary palaeo-channels and there are areas of calcrete, gravel

16.text: and mixed facies silts and sands.

17.text: Some  of  the  tenement  has  been  prospected  for  alluvial  gold  and  this  area  is  also

text:
underlain by Recent and Tertiary alluvium of the Gascoyne River. This alluvium includes 
 Recent channels as well as Tertiary palaeo-channels and there are areas of calcrete, gravel 
 and mixed facies silts and sands. 
 Some  of  the  tenement  has  been  prospected  for  alluvial  gold  and  this  area  is  also 
 prospective for uranium in Tertiary calcrete palaeo-channels.

26.text: Range.  It  is  still  a  good  prospecting  ground  for  metal  detectors  today  and  every  year

text:
The  district  has  been  exploited  since  1897  when  large  nuggets  were  discovered  by 
 prospectors  in  a  conglomerate  deposit  found  in  gullies  at  the  foot  of  the  Horseshoe 
 Range.  It  is  still  a  good  prospecting  ground  for  metal  detectors  today  and  every  year 
 nuggets are found, although the average size is generally less than one quarter of an inch. 
 Exploration  by  large  mining  companies  began  with  the  revival  of  modern  mineral 
 exploration  in  the  1980’s  and  saw  the  pegging  of  large  lease  areas  in  the  Peak  Hill 
 district.  This  was  generated  by  companies  such  as  Barrack  Exploration,  Dominion 
 Mining  and Homestake Gold. 
 More  recent  work  in  the  1990’s  by  Sons  of  Gwalia,  Dominion,  Plutonic/Homestake, 
 Afmeco,  Troy  Resources,  Sabminco,  Mines  and  Resources  Australia  and  Perilya 
 Resources  defined  areas  of  economic  interest.  New  mines  were  started  and  old  mines 
 revived including Horseshoe Lights, Fortnum, Labouchere and Horseshoe Gold/Cassidy 
 The potential of the area is well proven, but historic reports suggest that a thorough and 
 integrated approach was not undertaken and efforts were usually ceased after initial work 
 returned results of less than one ounce per ton. The potential of the lease therefore still 
 Over  the  lease  area  some  regional  and  reconnaissance  soil  sampling  programs  were 
 completed by Geochemex, Sabor and Barrack. However these were at wide spacing and 
 did not conclude with any significant result for gold. No records of any drilling have been 
 found for this lease. There is also no evidence of uranium exploration on the E52/2115

text:
During  the  period  of  the  report  an  analysis  of  historic  exploration  data  from  company 
 reports, published reports and the WAMEX (DOIR) database was completed and the results 
 to date are summarized below: 
 o  The  Proterozoic  geology  and  more  recent  regolith  geology  were  compiled from the 
 GSWA 1:250,000 scale base and presented as a regional map (See Figure 2).

12.text: o  Geochemistry data was gleaned from reports and was of limited use

13.text: o  Structural data from Landsat, Air Photo and Air Magnetic images were collated and

14.text: transferred to a scale useful for understanding the tenements in detail.

15.text: o  Interpretation of linear and folded structures and the generation of several conceptual

16.text: targets  for  gold.  Some  of  these  structural  features  are  coincident  with  linears

17.text: interpreted from aeromagnetics and geological contacts.

22.text: completed  over  this  area  (Peak  Hill  District)  in  the  period  between  1980  and  1998  by

23.text: Aerodata.  Detailed,  Ground  Magnetic,  Low-Level  Airborne  Magnetic  and/or  Induced

24.text: Polarization Surveys were conducted by private, larger mining companies on specific claim

25.text: areas,  but  there  are  no  records  for  the  Horseshoe  Gold  tenement.  Airborne  magnetometer

26.text: data at 1:25,000 scale is available from a 1991 Aerodata multi-client survey and has allowed

27.text: closer  definition  of  regional  structures  passing through the tenement and assisted with the

30.text: However,  there  was  a  need  for  more  detailed  and  newer  information  on  geophysics,

31.text: particularly radiometric, TMI and residual/enhanced derivative air magnetometer data.

33.text: Interpretations using the old data are consistent with GSWA interpreted bedrock units.

37.text: Scene  coverage  of  the  Peak  Hill  district  from  the  Landsat  ETM-7  (2001)  data  has  been

38.text: analysed and used for interpretation of geology, regolith and structural lineations. The high

39.text: albedo reflectance of sericite, quartz-rich or kaolin-bearing clays is highlighted on the ETM-

40.text: 7 image and is interpreted to correspond with hydrothermal or metamorphic alteration in the

41.text: host rocks. Likewise, areas of iron-rich and manganese-rich material in the form of laterites

42.text: or ferruginous weathering zones show up well on the images. Rock outcrops, subcrops and

43.text: mining areas produce discrete patterns and can be easily identified. The nature, extent and

44.text: flow direction of alluvium-filled drainages can be readily mapped from the ETM-7 image.

45.text: An accurate picture of recent, transported materials as well as older, more evenly distributed

46.text: colluvium and regolith zones can also be obtained, provided that the scale of the image and

47.text: the pixel clarity is detailed enough. There is a requirement for better quality images so that

48.text: more accurate mapping of rock unit boundaries can be achieved.

52.text: During February 2008 GPX Airborne Services completed a grid survey of Air Magnetics

53.text: and  Radiometrics  over  the  lease.  This  was  completed  at  a  line  spacing  of  100m  and  a

text:
o  Geochemistry data was gleaned from reports and was of limited use  
 o  Structural data from Landsat, Air Photo and Air Magnetic images were collated and 
 transferred to a scale useful for understanding the tenements in detail. 
 o  Interpretation of linear and folded structures and the generation of several conceptual 
 targets  for  gold.  Some  of  these  structural  features  are  coincident  with  linears 
 interpreted from aeromagnetics and geological contacts.  
 Geophysics Data Compilation 
 Government  airborne  regional  magnetics,  gravity  and  radiometric  surveys  have  been 
 completed  over  this  area  (Peak  Hill  District)  in  the  period  between  1980  and  1998  by 
 Aerodata.  Detailed,  Ground  Magnetic,  Low-Level  Airborne  Magnetic  and/or  Induced 
 Polarization Surveys were conducted by private, larger mining companies on specific claim 
 areas,  but  there  are  no  records  for  the  Horseshoe  Gold  tenement.  Airborne  magnetometer 
 data at 1:25,000 scale is available from a 1991 Aerodata multi-client survey and has allowed 
 closer  definition  of  regional  structures  passing through the tenement and assisted with the 
 generation of gold exploration targets.  
 However,  there  was  a  need  for  more  detailed  and  newer  information  on  geophysics, 
 particularly radiometric, TMI and residual/enhanced derivative air magnetometer data. 
 Interpretations using the old data are consistent with GSWA interpreted bedrock units.  
 Landsat and Aerial Photography 
 Scene  coverage  of  the  Peak  Hill  district  from  the  Landsat  ETM-7  (2001)  data  has  been 
 analysed and used for interpretation of geology, regolith and structural lineations. The high 
 albedo reflectance of sericite, quartz-rich or kaolin-bearing clays is highlighted on the ETM-
 7 image and is interpreted to correspond with hydrothermal or metamorphic alteration in the 
 host rocks. Likewise, areas of iron-rich and manganese-rich material in the form of laterites 
 or ferruginous weathering zones show up well on the images. Rock outcrops, subcrops and 
 mining areas produce discrete patterns and can be easily identified. The nature, extent and 
 flow direction of alluvium-filled drainages can be readily mapped from the ETM-7 image. 
 An accurate picture of recent, transported materials as well as older, more evenly distributed 
 colluvium and regolith zones can also be obtained, provided that the scale of the image and 
 the pixel clarity is detailed enough. There is a requirement for better quality images so that 
 more accurate mapping of rock unit boundaries can be achieved. 
 Tenement Geophysical Surveys 
 During February 2008 GPX Airborne Services completed a grid survey of Air Magnetics 
 and  Radiometrics  over  the  lease.  This  was  completed  at  a  line  spacing  of  100m  and  a

7.text: Another airborne survey was completed in the reporting period. This was undertaken by

8.text: HyVista Corporation Pty Ltd as a high-resolution spectral image survey which recorded

9.text: the  albedo  responses  from  known  mineral  wavelengths  present  at  surface.  This  survey

10.text: remains to be processed and analysed before target interpretation can begin. Results will

11.text: be reported in the next reporting period.

15.text: Using a combination of uranium, potassium, thorium and total counts with magnetics or

16.text: elevation models the tenement was subjected to analysis for:

19.text:  Target areas where combined effects were of interest

21.text: The map of uranium count contours shows a large E-W alluvial drainage anomaly that is

22.text: approximately 6.5 kilometres across and extends for about 28 kilometres along the length

23.text: of the lease within the alluvial plain of the Gascoyne River. There are also several smaller

24.text: anomalies. All the anomalous areas have a radiometric reading in the order of 5.2 to 6.9

25.text: ppm (orange/red colour in the map below) against the aircraft background of 0.37 ppm U

26.text: count in the area. Therefore the anomalies are considered real and indicate that uranium

27.text: is present at about 16 times background.

29.text: The magnetic patterns also show a strongly defined E-W alluvial channel zone, probably

30.text: from  the  magnetic  minerals  in  the  calcretes,  alluvial  laterites  and  detrital  channel  fill

31.text: deposits  within  the  Gascoyne  River  Tertiary  and  Recent  deposition  sequence.  Some

32.text: magnetic linear features of west-northwest or east-northeast orientation are also present.

33.text: These  could  be  basement  faults  or  fractures.  The  strong  magnetic  signatures  within  an

34.text: west-trending  drainage  across  the  tenement  may  be  buried  channels  since  they  are  not

35.text: identical to the current river channels and lie oblique to them. Where these are coincident

36.text: with high uranium response radiation counts they are significant targets.

38.text: If  the  uranium  count  and  1st  Vertical  Derivative  Magnetics  are  superimposed  it  can  be

39.text: seen  that  the  anomalous  uranium  areas  are  related  to  surface  as  well  as  sub-surface

40.text: drainage features in the two tenements. There are significant parallel magnetic high and

41.text: uranium-bearing  anomalies  that  may  reflect  older  drainages,  perhaps  palaeo-channels.

42.text: The  current  Gascoyne  River  has  a  strong  influence  and  overprint  on  the  drainage  and

43.text: tends to mask or cover some of its older channels.

45.text: Target generation from the various geophysical results is currently being undertaken and

46.text: will form the basis of the next year’s exploration program.

text:
were the spot heights for a Digital Elevation Model for each area 
 Another airborne survey was completed in the reporting period. This was undertaken by 
 HyVista Corporation Pty Ltd as a high-resolution spectral image survey which recorded 
 the  albedo  responses  from  known  mineral  wavelengths  present  at  surface.  This  survey 
 remains to be processed and analysed before target interpretation can begin. Results will 
 be reported in the next reporting period. 
 Interpretation of Geophysics 
 Using a combination of uranium, potassium, thorium and total counts with magnetics or 
 elevation models the tenement was subjected to analysis for: 
  Surface drainage features 
  Sub-surface structures 
  Target areas where combined effects were of interest 
 The map of uranium count contours shows a large E-W alluvial drainage anomaly that is 
 approximately 6.5 kilometres across and extends for about 28 kilometres along the length 
 of the lease within the alluvial plain of the Gascoyne River. There are also several smaller 
 anomalies. All the anomalous areas have a radiometric reading in the order of 5.2 to 6.9 
 ppm (orange/red colour in the map below) against the aircraft background of 0.37 ppm U 
 count in the area. Therefore the anomalies are considered real and indicate that uranium 
 is present at about 16 times background. 
 The magnetic patterns also show a strongly defined E-W alluvial channel zone, probably 
 from  the  magnetic  minerals  in  the  calcretes,  alluvial  laterites  and  detrital  channel  fill 
 deposits  within  the  Gascoyne  River  Tertiary  and  Recent  deposition  sequence.  Some 
 magnetic linear features of west-northwest or east-northeast orientation are also present. 
 These  could  be  basement  faults  or  fractures.  The  strong  magnetic  signatures  within  an 
 west-trending  drainage  across  the  tenement  may  be  buried  channels  since  they  are  not 
 identical to the current river channels and lie oblique to them. Where these are coincident 
 with high uranium response radiation counts they are significant targets. 
 If  the  uranium  count  and  1st  Vertical  Derivative  Magnetics  are  superimposed  it  can  be 
 seen  that  the  anomalous  uranium  areas  are  related  to  surface  as  well  as  sub-surface 
 drainage features in the two tenements. There are significant parallel magnetic high and 
 uranium-bearing  anomalies  that  may  reflect  older  drainages,  perhaps  palaeo-channels. 
 The  current  Gascoyne  River  has  a  strong  influence  and  overprint  on  the  drainage  and 
 tends to mask or cover some of its older channels. 
 Target generation from the various geophysical results is currently being undertaken and 
 will form the basis of the next year’s exploration program.
